Class Player

java.lang.Object
  Player

public class Player
extends Object

To keep track of "white" and "black" (and perhaps more colors someday) Might want to be singletons someday?

Version:
(2012 Apr 18)
Author:
(Mike Roam)

getStartOfFinalQuadrant

public int getStartOfFinalQuadrant()
replacing the specific white and black bear off zones that Board had so that I can use a single for loop for either color (incrementing using the Player.nextPoint( ) method below)

inBoardZone

public boolean inBoardZone(int i)
utility for checking that a number is in the range of numbered points on the board. Note: "inclusive" range! 1 and 24 are in range but bearOffLoc and beyondBearOffLoc are NOT!

inFinalQuadrant

public boolean inFinalQuadrant(int i)
utility for checking that a number is in the final quadrant on the board. Note: only 6 points are in this quadrant, not bearOffLoc and beyondBearOffLoc!

inRange

public boolean inRange(int i,
                       int oneEnd,
                       int otherEnd)
utility for checking that a number is in a range. Note: "inclusive" range! 3 and 5 are in range "3..5"

legitColor

public boolean legitColor()
Tells us if a Player's color is legal (only black and white currently allowed). See legitColor if you're checking points, which can also be "neutral" color. usage "if (player.legitColor( )) { ..."

legitColor

public static boolean legitColor(int color)

nextPoint

public int nextPoint(int currPoint)
So we can walk from starting "low" point to bear-off zone high points black moves from (low) 24 to 1 (0), white moves from (low) 1 to 24 (25)

Parameters:
currPoint - must be 1..howManyPoints
Returns:
for black return --currPoint, white gets ++currPoint BEWARE: use inBoardZone( ) or inFinalQuadrant( ) when looping, DON'T use < or > or == or != since we might be counting backwards! Note: this might go out of bounds and return Board.WHITE_BEAR_OFF_LOC, Board.BLACK_BEAR_OFF_LOC, but not Board.WHITE_PAST_BEAR_OFF_LOC, or Board.BLACK_PAST_BEAR_OFF_LOC

prevPoint

public int prevPoint(int currPoint)
So we can walk from starting "low" point to bear-off zone high points black moves from (low) 24 to 1 (0), white moves from (low) 1 to 24 (25)

Parameters:
currPoint - must be 1..howManyPoints
Returns:
for black return ++currPoint, white gets --currPoint BEWARE: use inBoardZone( ) or inFinalQuadrant( ) when looping, DON'T use < or > or == or != since we might be counting backwards! Note: this might go out of bounds and return Board.WHITE_BEAR_OFF_LOC, Board.BLACK_BEAR_OFF_LOC, but not Board.WHITE_PAST_BEAR_OFF_LOC, or Board.BLACK_PAST_BEAR_OFF_LOC

theReversePlayerColor

public Player theReversePlayerColor()
If given white, this returns black, and vice-versa. If we ever get a game with more than 2 colors, this will die, and so will its caller 'howImportantIsThisPoint( )'

toString

public String toString()
colorName. Was wordy "[player black]" but is now "black"

Overrides:
toString in class Object
